title: 111_hr3694
content: The Act may be cited as the "Removing Excess Litigation Involving Energy on Federal Lands Act" or the "RELIEF Act." The United States spends over $1 billion per day on importing crude oil, which is the largest wealth transfer in history. There are significant oil and gas reserves in the outer Continental Shelf, but legal challenges by environmental groups delay access to these resources, costing the American public and economy. Congress deems expedited judicial review necessary to prevent abuse of the judicial system. Exclusive jurisdiction over causes and claims related to covered energy projects is granted to the United States District Court for the District of Columbia. All claims must be filed within 60 days of the action or decision by a Federal official, or they will be barred. SEC. 5. DISTRICT COURT FOR THE DISTRICT OF COLUMBIA DEADLINE. All proceedings subject to section 3 must be resolved within 180 days of filing and take precedence over other matters. Failure to meet the deadline results in dismissal with prejudice. SEC. 6. ABILITY TO SEEK APPELLATE REVIEW. Only the Supreme Court can review judgments from the district court. SEC. 7. DEADLINE FOR APPEAL TO THE SUPREME COURT. SEC. 7. DEADLINE FOR APPEAL TO THE SUPREME COURT. If a writ of certiorari is granted by the Supreme Court, the district court's judgment must be resolved within 180 days. All proceedings take precedence over other matters before the Supreme Court. SEC. 8. LIMITATION ON SCOPE OF REVIEW AND RELIEF. SEC. 8. LIMITATION ON SCOPE OF REVIEW AND RELIEF. In judicial review of Federal actions, administrative findings are presumed correct unless proven otherwise with clear evidence. Prospective relief must be narrowly drawn and minimally intrusive to correct violations. SEC. 9. LEGAL FEES. SEC. 9. LEGAL FEES. Any person filing a petition for judicial review under this Act must pay prevailing parties' fees unless the Court finds their position justified. SEC. 10. EXCLUSION. This Act does not apply to disputes between lease parties. SEC. 11. COVERED ENERGY PROJECT DEFINED. SEC. 11. COVERED ENERGY PROJECT DEFINED. A covered energy project refers to any Federal official's action or decision regarding leasing Federal lands for energy exploration, development, production, processing, or transmission, including actions under such a lease.
